comments.commentBody:
It's about time; an obvious choice.
Sadly, it seems to be the only thing our clueless Dems have to offer besides being less catastrophic than Mitt, that far-out professor of Western Civilization. I can sleep better tonight, having learned the superior aspects of the Anglo-Saxon and Jewish cultures. We could all improve a bit by aspiring to their fine examples.

Once again one feels sad for our nation that our only other political party came up this person. Have they gotten so blind for their hatred for Obama that they could not find a better candidate. GOP has hit the bottom and is likely to better at polls. How can one not feel sad?

This sounds like something John Bolton would say, so I think we are seeing Bolton's influence on Romney's foreign policy. The fact that Romney has brought in so many Bush foreign-policy advisors should be a major theme of Obama's campaign.
I think we see now why Romney's team was so dead set against any coverage of his remarks.
Perhaps the most (okay, the only) endearing trait Governor Romney has is his ability to make us all think George W. was, in  comparison, articulate, tactful and positively presidential.

To quote - referring to Romney:
"Mr. Erekat said. “It seems to me this man lacks information, knowledge, vision and understanding of this region and its people.”

Also as well, the same can be said about Romney's read on we the people here in the USA.

Romney is simply a dim bulb - not very bright and surely not very well informed. Do we really need another round of this kind of simpleton.
We simply cannot afford it - or him.

Does Governor Romney understand the nature of the country of which he wants to be President? We are especially diverse. Our economic centers are filled with people of different cultures coming together and achieving greatness.
Mitt Romney's vision of an Anglo-Saxon America is scary. I would expect more sensitivity and understanding from a man who is a member of a highly maligned minority group like the Mormons.
how about replacing "neighbor" with "occupying foreign power" and then you might understand.

Just imagine how advanced the economies of the West Bank and Gaza would be, how much improved the lives of the people would be if, instead of heralding their martyrs and engaging in 'intifadas', the Palestinian people had turned their energies to developing their natural resources and human potential.

What if children were taught math and technology rather than hatred of their Jewish neighbours?

Suppose Palestinians put their energies into increasing cooperation with Israelis across the border, would there have been any need for trade restrictions?

As an alternative to acquiring missiles and rockets to be shot daily into Israel, might the leaders of the Palestinians consider investing their dollars and efforts into developing infrastructure?

Think of how much closer they would be to being citizens of their own country!

A future Palestinian state should seek to emulate Asian countries that have emphasized education, infrastructure, trust, and managed to sustain high levels of economic growth by adopting a positive outward orientation and integrating into world supply chains.

That is what is meant by culture.

Oh ple-e-e-ase. He didn't have to fawn over donors AND denigrate someone else at the same time. He could have complimented the Israeli people about making "the desert bloom". Oh, that was achieved in part by encouraging collective farms (kibbutzim), and government spending on infrastructure, which, of course are a form of that dreaded threat to democracy: SOCIALISM. If you still don't get it, he could have said nice things about Israel without disparaging Ecuador and Mexico (where his father was born) as well. Instead his campaign emphasized the latter slurs in trying to SPIN his comments about Palestinians.
Besides, how much foreign aid does the P.A. get from the US, vs. what Israel gets.
Oh please. Such selective moral outrage here. Regardless of what Romney says, one side or the other will be offended. Give me a break.

I think spend oodles of $$$ on end of life care is ridiculous and unsustainable.  We need to 'allow/be allowed' to die--the way it used to be!  That needs to be a 'new' conversation in this country.  76 million AGING baby boomers means lots of conversations about how we die!
Whow!   He(CFO) is all American?  He belongs in a bananna Republic. People like him are making this a third world country.

I agree with "What Next" from Kansas. The Affordable Health Care Act, does protect the consumer - citizen. I hope she can spread the word because the majority of Kansas citizens appear Republican and believe Obama and AHC act are worhless.

Dr. M. Denburg, Iowa
That their voters and viewers, respectfully, are suckers.
Hey, the Republicans and Fox News never mentioned this!  What else did they fail to tell us?

wow!  what a novel idea,  holding United States  private health insurers to an ethical standard.  They must have been brought kicking, biting and screaming to this new standard,  and I'll bet all that this idea didn't come from their boardroom!!
Love Kaiser Permanente here in CA!

If you have pre-existing conditions & haven't had insurance for 6 mos, you can get insurance now, if you have been denied insurance. Go to www.pcip.gov (click on state to see cost). My 40 year old son lost his job and insurance 2 years ago. He has 2 pre-exisiting conditions (acute pancreatitis w/pancreatic cyst & high blood pressure) After 6 months he got on ACA's PCIP (Pre-Existing Insurance Plan). He pays $188 (age 35-44) a month in AZ, has $25 co-pays, includes an RX plan for his meds. He kept his same PC doctor, saw 3 specialists, had CT scan &blood test to see if he needed surgery . He is now working part-time and is able to afford his insurance. Has not had doctors refuse the insurance.This program works as well as my Medicare, which I love. Doctors care & medications have kept him out of the hospital for the past year.
I have friends with 2 disabled small children. They own small business and bought insurance for themselves but had never been able to get insurance for kids. They now have their girls on PCIP at $104 each (age 0-19 price).
So if you have a pre-existing condition and have been denied insurance, you don't have to wait until 2014 to get on PCIP . Cost varies by state because some states have the Federal Government managing the program (AZ) and some states manage their own.
The toll free number at the website will connect you with people who can tell you if you qualify and they were wonderfully helpful and cooperative.

The people with the big voices and lots of capital to put out publications and release news are obviously the folks who run the business ... healthcare is a business in this country. Doctors are opting to buy lower quality diagnostic devices and charge you as much or more than a hospital version of the same test... and they have a hard time reading poor quality output... and they don't do it often enough to be good at it... So go to a hospital even if the doc says his patients Always let him do it.
Most people don't know the facts. Tell them... like you did here... that you can see that government or single payer is the way to go for the best healthcare. But we need rules out there to prevent the over use of MRI for example by doctors who own the machines... or get a kickback for referrals to a hospital. If your doc won't prescribe antibiotics for a previously determined case of diverticulitis but requires that you get ANOTHER CT scan with radioactive contrast, go see a different doctor. Huge expense when a simple prescription would make it go away. Not an addictive drug.

Again, you should check out what the FBI says abou tMedicare. Their actual overhead (reported) is about 5% in 2012. Their REAL overhead (unreported) is (reported) plus 11% plus lost to fraud, waste, and abuse because of a lousy control system and very little due dilligence in paying claims for a carrier that consumes $550Billion a year of your money.

Medicare is horribly run, wastes tons of money, and pays medical providers below costs for many things they pay for on behalf of seniors. That is making your private insurance more expensive.

There may be a good government solution out there, but I shudder to think we'd make it Medicare.

WR29

If in fact the administrative costs for Medicare are 3% and private insurers have in many cases been over 20%..............please explain to me why everyone is against "government" and for unfettered capitalism. Sounds to me like the sensible thing for this country is a single payer system. There is no way Aetna and United HealthCare are too big to fail. They're already run away with all our money and are set for life. Shameful.

Article says some received their check last week, so it may be in the mail, if you are due to receive one - check the list, here http://yourhealthsecurity.org/health-insurance-refund-list-2011

Last day for your insurance company to mail is tomorrow. Open all your envelopes.
Could anyone who gets one please take a picture of the envelope and post it so the rest of us can be on the look out for and not shred or chuck it unopened? Thanks!

Egads, no one in the article or in these 400 comments has thrown away a true grand piano. Even I would throw myself between a concert grand and one of the video's claw monsters--and I'm a brass player who distrusts any instrument that can have a single nonworking note.

The article should have distinguished better between grand pianos and pianos with the word "grand" in them, like "baby grand" and (the beneath-contempt, squarish) "parlor grand."

If you're piano is 7 feet long, it'll be loved. If it's less than 6 feet long, give it to Baker House at MIT if they'll take it (an oversimplification, but not much of one).
They are being delivered to the landfill, but there will be an opportunity first for the artists to claim them, and then for the community to.

I don't know what type of piano it was other than a grand, but I was walking through the Minneapolis Airport last week, and a flight attendant was playing right there in the midst of the hustle and bustle.  It was wonderful.  We need more pianos in more public places!   Save the pianos!
I'm at a loss for words.

I am among the many who bemoan, at the very least, the loss of that great old lumber. Being pragmatic about it I have to accept that the market has changed and moved away from these very heavy instruments of old. Still, old timber is typically understood to be of a quality that can't be had today. Heartbreaking to see it lost.

I gave my J.C. Fischer, still fine after about 85 years, to
http://www.my88keys.org/, 88Keys. It was placed in a class at a high school. This is local to northern California, but a good model for other places. Yes, it is impossible to get rid of one that is not in good shape musically. They are often great furniture, without the music, but not worth the moving costs.

Here in Minnesota, old pianos can be donated to a special charity:
http://keys44kids.com
